docs.title: About Nizubot
docs.text:
Nizubot aims to be a kitchen sink discord bot. That means it tries to do as much as possible. You can add Nizubot to your discord server, or use it as a user app.

To start using this bot, click here.

docs.title: User app commands
docs.text:
Not all commands are available if you use Nizubot as a user app. If a command is available on the user app, it will say so in the commands page.

Most user app commands also has an optional ephemeral field which decides if the message should be hidden from others. Defaults to False, so other users will see it. If there is no ephemeral option and the command is on the user app, it will always be hidden.

docs.title: Reading the Documentation
docs.text: Here's some things you should know when reading the docs.

docs.title: Command parameters
docs.text:
Here's how the parameters may be presented when reading about a command:

Parameter Description name This is a normal required parameter. description? If a parameter is optional, it will have a ``? at the end of it. (Default: Empty) emoji | role Parameters separated by a | means you can only use one of them. Inside of Discord, they will both be optional, but an error will be given if none/several are picked. So you can either pick an emoji, or a role, but not none or both. user? | image Same as the previous one, but if you pick none, the default value of the parameter with a ? will be used. For example, the ? on user might mean that it will default to selecting you. (Default: user: You) [ upper_text | lower_text ] Parameters separated by a | but surrounded by [ ... ] means you can pick more than one of the parameters. So you can now have an upper text, and a lower text, but you still can't have none, unless there's a ? on one of them. food_type This type has several choices. The choices will always be listed at the end of the description. (Burger | Pizza | Taco)

Most user app commands also has an optional ephemeral field which decides if the message should be hidden from others. This parameter will not be listed.

docs.title: /clear_bot_data
docs.text:
Parameter Description confirmation? Needs to be set to True to confirm clear. (Default: False)

Removes all data connected to the guild/user. The confirmation is optional so that you don't accidentally run the command.

docs.title: COTD Role Command.
docs.text: Allows you to have roles that changes based on the current COTD. (color of the day)

docs.title: /cotd_role create
docs.text:
Parameter Description name? The name of the role. (Default: "<cotd>") role? The role that will be updated.

Creates a new COTD role. If you use the name parameter, if you add "<cotd>" it will be replaced by the name of the current daily color. If the role parameter is left empty, Nizubot will create a new role.

docs.title: /cotd_role remove
docs.text:
Parameter Description delete? If the role should be deleted from the guild. (Default: False)

Stops updating the current COTD role. If you set delete to True, it will also delete the role from the guild.

docs.title: Detect Message Command.
docs.text: Allows you to add message detectors with custom responses.

docs.title: /detect_message add
docs.text:
Parameter Description detect_type How the detection should happen. (Starts with | Contains | Ends with | Equals) key The text that should be detected. response The response after detecting it. case_sensitive? If the detection should be case sensitive or not. (Default: False)

Creates a new detector that will detect certain messages and respond to them.

docs.title: /detect_message remove
docs.text:
Parameter Description index The index of the detector you wanna remove.

Removes a detector. You can get the index of the detector by running /detect_message list. Keep in mind the index of a detector may change if you remove a detector in the middle of the list. May change in the future. Spam me on discord if I haven't.

docs.title: /detect_message list
docs.text: Lists all of your current message detectors in the server, or in the bots DMs.

docs.title: Log Command.
docs.text: Logs for debugging.

docs.title: /log get
docs.text: Gives you all log messages from the last 12 hours connected to the server / you.

docs.title: /log add
docs.text:
Parameter Description message The message to add to the logs.

Adds a log message to the logs. You can see it when you run /log get, and the webhook logger will have sent it if you have it enabled.

docs.title: /log add_webhook
docs.text:
Parameter Description webhook_url? Url to an existing webhook if you don't want the bot to create a new webhook. (Required if running in DMs)

Makes the bot use a webhook to send logs.

docs.title: /log remove_webhook
docs.text: Makes the bot no longer use a webhook to send logs.

docs.title: Lua Command.
docs.text: Allows you to create/manage custom guild commands with Lua.

docs.title: /lua command create
docs.text:
Parameter Description command_name The name of the command. description The description of the command. params? The parameters of the command. (Default: None) lua_file The Lua file which has the code.

Creates a guild command which runs the provided Lua file. The Lua file needs to return a function, and this function will get run every time the command gets called. The function will get 2 parameters: ctx and args. To reply, use ctx:reply("content"), and to read the arguments, do args.argument_name. For more info about creating commands, click here.

docs.title: /lua command update
docs.text:
Parameter Description command_name The name of the command you want to update. description? The updated description of the command. (Default: Current description) params? The updated parameters of the command. (Default: Current params) lua_file? The updated Lua file which has the code. (Default: Current file)

There's only one required parameter, which is the name of the command you want to update. Every other parameter is optional. If you don't use a parameter, the current value will be used instead.

docs.title: /lua command delete
docs.text:
Parameter Description command_name The name of the command you want to delete.

Deletes a guild command.

docs.title: /lua command download
docs.text:
Parameter Description command_name The name of the command you want to download.

Sends the Lua file of the guild command.

docs.title: /lua command refresh
docs.text: Re-sends the guild command info to Discord in case the commands didn't update properly.

docs.title: /lua instance restart
docs.text:
Parameter Description force_quit? If you want to force quit all currently running commands. (Default: False)

Restarts the Lua instance.

docs.title: Manage Reminders Command.
docs.text: Used to moderate user reminders. If a user creates an inappropriate reminder, you'll be able to remove it with this command.

docs.title: /manage_reminders peek
docs.text:
Parameter Description user The user you wanna check the reminders for.

Checks which reminders a user has. The command will be ephemeral, so no one will see you ran it.

docs.title: /manage_reminders remove
docs.text:
Parameter Description user The user you wanna remove a reminder from. index The index of the reminder you wanna remove.

Removes a reminder from a user. The command will be ephemeral, so no one will see you ran it.

docs.title: Message Command.
docs.text: Allows you to manage messages.

docs.title: /message edit
docs.text:
Parameter Description message_id The message you want to edit. content? The contents of the message. embeds? The embeds of the message.

Edits a message sent by the bot. The message cannot be a message that is replying to another message or a command. It can only edit "regular" messages.

docs.title: /message send
docs.text:
Parameter Description content? The contents of the message. embeds? The embeds of the message.

Sends a new message and not show that it came from a command.

docs.title: /message analyze
docs.text:
Parameter Description message_id The message you wanna analyze.

Sends the raw data of the message.

docs.title: Reaction Role Command.
docs.text: Allows you to manage reaction roles. If you can, try using Discords onboarding feature instead of this.

docs.title: /reaction_role add
docs.text:
Parameter Description message_id The message you want to to add the reaction role to. emoji The emoji to react with. role The role to give.

Creates a reaction role for the specified message.

docs.title: /reaction_role remove
docs.text:
Parameter Description message_id The message you wanna remove the reaction role from. emoji | role The reaction role you wanna remove. Will remove whichever one has the emoji / role connected to it.

Removes a reaction role from a message.

docs.title: /reaction_role list
docs.text:
Parameter Description message_id? The message you wanna check reaction roles for.

Lists all reaction roles in the server / message.

docs.title: Genmeme Command
docs.text:
This command is used to generate memes.

Note

Command is also available on the user app.

docs.title: /genmeme brick
docs.text:
Parameter Description user? | image The user/image to throw the brick. (Default: user: You)

Generates a gif of someone throwing a brick.

docs.title: /genmeme petpet
docs.text:
Parameter Description user? | image The user/image to be petted. (Default: user: You)

Generates a gif of someone getting petted.

docs.title: /genmeme caption
docs.text:
Parameter Description caption_type The type of caption you want. (WHAT | White boxes | Overlay text) user | image The user/image you want to be captioned. [ upper_text | bottom_text ] The text written at the top and bottom. font_size? The size of the font.Defaults:caption_type = WHAT: "width / 7"caption_type = White boxes: "width / 10"caption_type = Overlay text: "height / 10" break_height? Height of the space between new lines. (Default: "font_size / 4") padding? Empty space around the text.Defaults:caption_type = WHAT: "width / 9"caption_type = White boxes: "width / 20"caption_type = Overlay text: "height / 30"

Adds captions to an image / users pfp.

docs.title: Caption examples
docs.text: WHATWhite boxesOverlay text

docs.title: /cotd
docs.text:
Parameter Description day? Which day you wanna check the color for. (Default: Today)

Gives you the color of the day. The color is randomly decided every day. It works by generating a random color and then picking the closest color from this project.

docs.title: /echo
docs.text:
Parameter Description content What you want the bot to say.

Simply just repeats what the user put inside of content.

docs.title: /eval
docs.text:
Parameter Description expression The math expression you want solved.

Simply just solves the math expression. Has a very limited amount of math functions, only sin and cos are available.

docs.title: Icon Command.
docs.text: Gets the icon of whatever you want. (might separate these into their own commands, like /pfp, /server_icon and /emoji_icon. idk tho)

docs.title: /icon user
docs.text:
Parameter Description user? The user you want the pfp from. (Default: You)

Gets the pfp of the user.

docs.title: /icon guild
docs.text: Gets the icon of the current guild. (Gives the bots pfp if ran in dms)

docs.title: /icon emoji
docs.text:
Parameter Description emoji The custom emoji you want the icon from.

Gets the icon of a custom emoji. Does not work with normal emojis, and the custom emoji must be from the guild you're currently running the command in.

docs.title: Join Order Command.
docs.text: See info related to when people joined a server.

docs.title: /join_order get
docs.text:
Parameter Description user? | index The user / index you wanna check. (Default: user: You)

See what order people joined at.

docs.title: /join_order graph
docs.text:
Parameter Description graph_data If you wanna graph when members joined or the total amount of members. (New members graph_type? If you want a line graph or a bar graph.Defaults:graph_data = New members: Line graphgraph_data = Total members: Bar graph entries? How many entries you want on the graph. (Default: Auto)

Get a graph of when people joined / how many members a server had.

Note

The graph only includes users that are currently in the server.

docs.title: /ping
docs.text: Gets the current ping of the bot.

docs.title: /rng
docs.text:
Parameter Description min? Smallest possible number. (Default: 0) max? Biggest possible number. (Default: 100)

Picks a random number from min to max. (Both are inclusive)

docs.title: Sleep Calc Command.
docs.text: Calculates the best time to go to sleep / wake up. The average human takes around 15 minutes to fall asleep. Once you are asleep you will go through sleep cycles. One sleep cycle is about 90 minutes and a good night's sleep consists of 5-6 sleep cycles. It's best to wake up at the end of a cycle to help you feel more rested and ready to start the day.\nI will calculate the best time for you to sleep/wake up by using this information.

docs.title: /sleep_calc sleep
docs.text:
Parameter Description wake_hour The hour of the time you wanna wake up. wake_minute The minute of the time you wanna wake up. time_format The format the time is in. (AM | PM | 24h clock) sleep_duration? The amount of minutes it takes for you to fall asleep. (Default: 15) cycle_length? How many minutes a sleep cycle takes for you. (Default: 90)

Calculates the best time to go to sleep.

docs.title: /sleep_calc wake
docs.text:
Parameter Description sleep_hour The hour of the time you wanna go to sleep. sleep_minute The minute of the time you wanna go to sleep. time_format The format the time is in. (AM | PM | 24h clock) sleep_duration? The amount of minutes it takes for you to fall asleep. (Default: 15) cycle_length? How many minutes a sleep cycle takes for you. (Default: 90)

Calculates the best time to go to wake up.

docs.title: /sleep_calc info
docs.text: Gives info about how the results are calculated. Basically the same at the text at the top of this page.

docs.title: Check Timezone Command
docs.text:
Command for checking the time in different timezones.

Note

Command is also available on the user app.

docs.title: /check_timezone
docs.text:
Parameter Description timezone The timezone you wanna check the time for.

Checks the time in that timezone.

docs.title: Currency Command
docs.text:
This command is used to convert to/from currencies.

Note

Command is also available on the user app.

docs.title: /currency list
docs.text: Lists a few popular currencies. For a full list of supported currencies, click here.

docs.title: /currency convert
docs.text:
Parameter Description amount Amount of currency you wanna convert. from Currency to convert from. to Currency to convert to.

Converts currencies from one currency to another.

docs.title: Profile Command
docs.text:
Command for checking/changing your profile. The things you set on your profile will affect the output of some commands. For example, if you set your preferred time format to the 12-hour clock, the time on some commands will be formatted to your preference.

Note

Command is also available on the user app.

docs.title: /profile check
docs.text:
Parameter Description user? The user you wanna check the profile for. (Default: You)

Checks yours/someone elses profile.

docs.title: /profile clear
docs.text:
Parameter Description confirmation? Needs to be set to True to confirm clear. (Default: False)

Clears your profile data.

docs.title: /profile timezone set
docs.text:
Parameter Description timezone The timezone you want to set on your profile.

Sets your timezone to your profile.

docs.title: /profile timezone remove
docs.text: Removes your timezone from your profile.

docs.title: /profile time_format set
docs.text:
Parameter Description time_format Your preferred time format. (12-hour clock | 24-hour clock)

Sets your preferred time_format to your profile.

docs.title: /profile time_format remove
docs.text: Removes your preferred time_format from your profile.

docs.title: Remind Command
docs.text: This command is used to create/manage reminders.

docs.title: /remind add
docs.text:
Parameter Description duration When the reminder should go off. (Example: 1s 2m 3h 4d 5w 6y) message? Message to send with the reminder. looped? If the reminder should restart once finished. (Default: False)

Create a new reminder.

docs.title: /remind remove
docs.text:
Parameter Description index The index of the reminder you wanna remove.

Removes a reminder. You can get the index of the reminder by running /remind list. Keep in mind the index of a reminder may change, since they are sorted based on when the reminder goes off. May change in the future. Spam me on discord if I haven't.

docs.title: /remind list
docs.text: Lists all of your current reminders in the server, or in the bots DMs.

docs.title: Guild commands
docs.text: One thing you can do with the /lua command is to create and manage your own guild commands using Lua.

docs.title: Creating commands
docs.text: To create a guild command, you can use /lua command create. There's 2 required parameters. Those are for the name of the command, and for the file containing the code for the command. The file can be either a .lua or .luau file. There's also 2 optional parameters. One is for the description of the command, and the other is the parameters for the command.

docs.title: Writing the code for the command
docs.text:
Below is an example of a command. This command will get the celsius parameter from the user and return how many fahrenheit it's equal to. 

local function celsiusToFahrenheit(celsius)
    return celsius * (9/5) + 32
end

return function(ctx, args)
    local fahrenheit = celsiusToFahrenheit(args.celsius)
    ctx:reply(args.celsius.." celsius is equal to "..fahrenheit.." fahrenheit.")
end
This Lua code returns a function, and this function will be run every time the command gets called. The first parameter is a CommandContext which is used to reply to the command. The second parameter is just a table with all the parameters the user used when running the command.

docs.title: Writing the parameters for the command
docs.text:
The params field accepts a string which describes all the parameters for the command. Here's an example string for the command above: 

name=celsius:type=number:description=The amount of celsius you want to convert:required=true
To set a property, you put the name of the property, followed by a "=" and then the value of the property. Each property is separated by a ":". If you want more than one parameter, you separate them using ";". Here's an example of having several parameters: 
name=param1:type=number; name=param2:type=integer; name=param3:type=string;
The last ";" and the spaces are optional. The spaces are there to improve readability.

docs.title: Parameter properties
docs.text:
Here are the valid properties for a parameter:

Property Description name The name of the parameter. type The type of the parameter. See Parameter types for more info. description? The description of the parameter. required? If the parameter should be required or not.

docs.title: Parameter types
docs.text:
Here are the valid types for a parameter:

Type Description bool | boolean A true/false value. integer A whole number. number Any number. string A text value.

docs.title: Updating commands
docs.text: To update a guild command, you can use /lua command update. There's only one required parameter, which is the name of the command you want to update. Every other parameter is optional. If you don't use a parameter, the current value will be used instead.
